column1: Thorin Oakenshield wrote the message after the unexpected party in  and left it on Bilbos mantelpiece just under the clock.  The next morning
column3: Bilbo did not see the letter until Gandalf walked in and pointed it out.

column1: The letter began with a greeting to "Burglar Bilbo" and thanks for his hospitality and offer to help.  A short list of contract terms were then laid out
column2: promising Bilbo one fourteenth of the profits (if any)
column3: with travelling and funeral expenses covered.  The letter then explained that the Thorin and Company had gone ahead to make preparations and that Bilbo was expected at the Green Dragon Inn in Bywater at eleven.  A final sentence emphasized that Thorin expected him to arrive on time.

column1: By the time the hobbit had finished reading the note he had
column3: just ten minutes to get from Bag End to the Green Dragon in order to be on-time for the start of the quest to the Lonely Mountain.  Bilbo ran as fast as he could and made it on the stroke of eleven.

column1: Eventually Bilbo brought out Thorins letter in the camp of the Thranduil and Bard in the valley before the Lonely Mountain.  Bilbo had kept the crumpled and much folded missive in his jacket pocket throughout his adventures and used it to explain his interest in the matters at hand.
In the manuscript for The Hobbit Thorins letter (referred to as "Bilbos contract" by John D. Rateliff) was the same as the one published
column2: with the exception that the rendezvous point was the Old Mill.  However
column3: J.R.R. Tolkien also produced a handwritten version of the letter in tengwar

column7: in Rateliffs The History of The Hobbit as the frontispiece to Part Two: Return to Bag-End. The Tengwar text was semi-phonetical.
